node.title: ERROR: no FunctionName parameter named "node_n" found

node.bodyText: The kernel must define a function parameter in the validParams. You can’t just hardcode the function in the constructor, you have to have it as a parameter to use getFunction
yes，thank u

node.title: Incorporating a Pressure Drop Calculation
node.bodyText: I am using a pre-made pressure drop calculator, but I am getting the following error: "A 'PressureDrop' is not a registered object." . Will I have to update my version of MOOSE to use this object?

Hello
Maybe if your version of moose is really old. I added this object like 6 months ago or so
it s in the navier stokes module so you need to either use that module s executable or enable it in your application makefile
Guillaume

node.title: Surface Integral Setup
node.bodyText: I would like to determine the drag and lift force on an object in fluid flow using the surface integral involving the viscosity multiplied by the normal derivative of the fluid velocity summed with the surface integral of the normal pressure. Is there an example of setting up a post processor to accomplish this?

@grmnptr just made a pull request to add this for finite volume. It should be in the framework soon.
Do you need this for FE or FV fluid flow?
Thanks for the response. I would like to implement this in FE for fluid flow.
It should be very similar for FE we just need to add the computeQpIntegral implementation on those postprocessors

node.title: Moose Representation for Normal Derivatives and Directional Derivatives
node.bodyText: Some codes allow for access to the values for the normal derivative in the following way, nx, ny, etc., and directional derivatives as ux, px, uy, etc.. How can these values be applied for use in MOOSE, and what is their syntax?

Hello
so normal near a boundary?
for directional derivative you can retrieve a gradient using coupledGradient(“name of variable parameter”)
for normal derivatives, use the gradient and the _normals attribute defined near boundaries only
Guillaume
Thank you for the guidance.

node.title: Compile Error in libmesh on cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I tried to build MOOSE on the cluster following the page https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html, I encounter the following error when compile libmesh:
../src/mesh/xdr_io.C: In member function 'void libMesh::XdrIO::read_serialized_connectivity(libMesh::Xdr&, libMesh::dof_id_type, const std::vector<long unsigned int>&, T)':
../src/mesh/xdr_io.C:1844:17: error: invalid initializer for structured binding declaration
       for (auto [e, it] = std::tuple{first_elem, conn.begin()}; e<last_elem; e++)
                 ^~~~~~~
  CXX      src/numerics/libmesh_opt_la-dense_submatrix.lo
  CXX      src/numerics/libmesh_opt_la-dense_subvector.lo
make[1]: *** [src/mesh/libmesh_opt_la-xdr_io.lo] Error 1
make[1]: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
make[1]: Leaving directory `/scratch/users/chunhui3/projects/moose/libmesh/build'
make: *** [all-recursive] Error 1

I'm using the following modules:
 1) gcc/7.2.0                  2) cmake/3.18.4               3) mvapich2/2.3.6-gcc-7.2.0

It appears to me that gcc may be at a lower version that minimum requirement (GCC @ 7.5.0), I use 7.2.0 because it seems to be compatible with cmake version, any suggestions on what should I do? Thanks a lot

Use a newer GCC. The minimum requirements are a hard limit.
Since this is INL HPC there s plenty of newer ones and there s lots that work with local cmake modules too
Thanks Guid. I'm trying to build this on our university cluster as well. I would discuss with the experts there to help me set up the newer version of cmake.

After using a higher version of gcc, the libmesh is successfully built. However, when I run the make -j4 inside test folder, it gives the following error:

It seems like the "Python" package is the problem, any suggestion? I load the following modules:
[chunhui3@golubh3 moose]$ module list
Currently Loaded Modulefiles:
  1) cmake/3.18.4              2) gcc/8.2.0                 3) openmpi/4.1.4-gcc-8.2.0

Now you need to load an appropriate Python package. We recommend something between Python >=3.8 and <=3.10.
Python 3.7 is end of life as of last month. So that version you seem to have there (3.2) is super old... Here is a version support matrix for convenience: https://devguide.python.org/versions/
Thanks! I have successfully build and pass the test after loading python 3.9.16

node.title: *** ERROR *** Cyclic dependency detected in object ordering: burgers <- ini_stress <- burgers
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
I created a 2D simple tunnel (small circle + square outside) to model the creep behavior using Burgers model (kelvin_voigt representation), and try to set in-situ stress in the model using ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress (without this, the model seems works well),
but if add ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress it always shows this error:
*** ERROR *** Cyclic dependency detected in object ordering: burgers <- ini_stress <- burgers
Any suggestion to resolve this issue?
Here is the core block from input file:
[Kernels]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    add_variables = true
    strain = SMALL
    planar_formulation = PLANE_STRAIN
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
   # use_displaced_mesh = true
    incremental = true
    volumetric_locking_correction=false
    eigenstrain_names = ini_stress
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./burgers] #kelvin_voigt
    # type = GeneralizedMaxwellModel
    type = GeneralizedKelvinVoigtModel
    creep_modulus = '12000'
    creep_viscosity = '100 18000'
    poisson_ratio = 0.2
    young_modulus = 12000
    driving_eigenstrain=ini_stress
  [../]
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'creep'
    tangent_operator='nonlinear'
   # damage_model= damage
    perform_finite_strain_rotations = false
  [../]
  [./creep]
    type = LinearViscoelasticStressUpdate
  [../]
  [./strain]
    type = ComputeIncrementalSmallStrain
    volumetric_locking_correction=false
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    eigenstrain_names = ini_stress
  [../]
  [./ini_stress]
    type = ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress
    initial_stress = '-5 0 0 0 -5 0 0 0 0'
    eigenstrain_name = ini_stress
  [../]
#  [./ini_stress]
#    type = ComputeEigenstrain
#    eigenstrain_name = ini_stress
#    eigen_base = '-0.00026 0 0  0 -0.00026 0  0 0 0'
 # [../]
[]


[UserObjects]
  [./update]
    type = LinearViscoelasticityManager
    viscoelastic_model = burgers
  [../]
[]

Thank you very much for your help.
Best regards,
:D

Hello
Converted to discussions until we know for sure it's a bug.
You could duplicate the stress model to remove the cyclic dependency I think
otherwise @WilkAndy made this object
Guillaume
Thanks @GiudGiud, could you please elaborate on that? how to duplicate the stress model? thanks, Deyan

I m guessing if you set up prefixes for the material properties you can have the same stress model in two blocks. One of them for initialization
it s a tad hacky but worth a try

node.title: Calculation of strain energy density with the eigen strains
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts,
I am trying to add 2 way coupling from the paper as shown in attached figure.
I found one material kernel which can be used to evaluate the strain energy density but this is without eigen strains. I wonder if there is any material kernel to calculate the strain energy density with the eigen strains. Also, I want to calculate it for finite deformation problem.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/StrainEnergyDensity.html

Link to the article is https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378775316304074.
Thanks,
Avtar
@recuero @vanwdani

Strain energy density calculations should not include eigenstrains as these do not generate stresses. In this sense, the existing MOOSE object should do the job (it even seems that the equation you posted uses a single type of strain, with the subscript "e"; maybe for elastic).

Thanks @recuero. Does this strain energy density calculation involves only elastic strain or the total strain? I want to calculate the strain energy density only from the elastic part. Also, is it compatible with large deformation settings?

MOOSE computes the strain energy density using the elastic strain (if you look in the code it may not be called exactly that, e.g. _strain_increment, but it's the elastic strain). Yes, it is compatible with large deformation kinematics.

node.title: define a global variable that needs to be updated after every substep
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone. I am using MOOSE to run the CPFE simulation. I have a global variable which needs to loop every _qp to obtain. Besides, this variable needs to be updated every substep. I try to implement it under Materials, but fail.
How can I realize this function? I think I should add an Userobjects in my APP. Would you please simply write down the loop for each _qp and fine the maximum _pk2?

Hello
this seems like the behavior for a postprocessor
If you write down the behavior that should happen at every quadrature point you can use the postprocessor loop to get it to do what you want
Guillaume

node.title: has signature for Assembly.cacheResidual/Jacobian() changed recently?
node.bodyText:
I recently updated my local copy of the framework and broke my app. I have a NodalKernel that has calls to _assembly.cacheResidual/Jacobian() to add some values to specific rows in the matrix. There were previously _vector_tags and _matrix_tags member variables that I blindly passed to the functions as the last argument.
After updating my framework and re-compiling my app, I get errors like: error: 'std::set<unsigned int> TaggingInterface::_vector_tags' is private within this context. How can I fix?

@lindsayad ok i lied, I'm using a NodalScalarKernel. Not sure if that matters.
Where are addResiduals and addJacobianElement defined? I assume these have the same effect as what cacheResidual/Jacobian did previously?
The Jacobian calls look similar in that you still pass the row, column, and value. The scaling factor is not applied here but is instead passed as well as the assembly reference. Seens straightforward.
How about the Residual calls? Previously I had _assembly.cacheResidual(_var.dofIndices()[0], computeQpResidual()*_var.scalingFactor(), _vector_tags). What's this std::array business?
It allows us to use the same API for both a single residual and a dynamically sized vector of residuals

Where are addResiduals and addJacobianElement defined?

You can see all the available APIs in TaggingInterface
What's the _qp = 0 doing in there? Doesn't seem to be used.
It's assumed that's is used in the derived class

OK, I think I got this figured out. Thanks for your help @lindsayad . I think the change is for the better since I don't have to bother with tags in my kernel and don't need to remember to apply the scaling factor.

node.title: Terminator based on max(feature_volumes)
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have the following code:
[Postprocessors]
   [./flood_count]
     type = FeatureFloodCount
     variable = stress_excess
     # Must be turned on to build data structures necessary for FeatureVolumeVPP
     compute_var_to_feature_map = true
     #threshold = 1e5
     threshold = 2.9e6
     execute_on = 'timestep_end'
     block = 'Fault1D Fault2D'
   [../]
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [./feature_volumes]
    type = FeatureVolumeVectorPostprocessor
    flood_counter = flood_count
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
    output_centroids = True
    single_feature_per_element = True
  [../]
[]

which generates the following output (prefix_feature_volumes_0001.csv):
centroid_x,centroid_y,centroid_z,feature_volumes,intersects_bounds,intersects_specified_bounds,percolated,var_num
4204.4794184423,2993.9039228218,-2984.99526698,264.76911241796,0,0,0,0
4209.0122646856,2989.0377517617,-2953.8534362391,637.41810668695,0,0,0,0
4209.0122646856,2989.0377517617,-2953.8534362391,637.41810668694,0,0,0,0
4204.4794184423,2993.9039228218,-2984.99526698,264.76911241796,0,0,0,0

I would like to trigger the terminator based on the maximum value of detected feature_volumes (if any).
(let say if max(feature_volumes) > 1000, triggers the Terminator.
Do you think it is possible?
Thanks in advance,
Thomas Ulrich.

Found the answer:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/VectorPostprocessorReductionValue.html
